landing_page.sectionTitle1: A writing tool for people seeking expungement
landing_page.sectionParagraph1: Expunge Assist helps you write a letter to a judge (a “declaration”). If you are applying to have your record expunged, a declaration can help.
landing_page.sectionParagraph2:
Expunge Assist is a free step-by-step tool that helps people with past convictions in California write a declaration. It is one part of the expungement process. This free tool is provided by Hack for LA, a project under the nonprofit Civic Tech Structure.

 Expunge Assist is not a replacement for legal advice.
landing_page.sectionParagraph3: This is a tool for people who are writing a declaration that addresses their progress and motivations for seeking expungement.
landing_page.sectionParagraph4:
We provide step-by-step guidance through the
process of writing and downloading a
declaration for expungement.
landing_page.sectionParagraph4BulletPoint1: Follow simple question prompts to know what and how much to say.
landing_page.sectionParagraph4BulletPoint2: Preview what you’ve written and make any changes after each section and at the end.
landing_page.sectionParagraph4BulletPoint3: When you’re happy with the declaration, download, copy, or email it to use in your application.
landing_page.sectionParagraph5a: This tool results in a complete and downloadable declaration.
landing_page.sectionParagraph5b: We recommend you meet with a lawyer or clinic to review the declaration before submitting it to a judge.
landing_page.sectionParagraph6:
Expunge Assist does not save your answers after you leave this website.

Save your declaration before leaving the website, and protect it as you would anything personal.
landing_page.section7Dropdown1Title: Why do I need a declaration?
landing_page.section7Dropdown1Paragraph:
When you file a petition with the court, you have the opportunity to attach a personal letter called a “declaration” explaining why you deserve a fresh start.

The declaration letter is your opportunity to explain to a judge why you want your criminal record cleared or your charges reduced. A declaration can help your case by adding your personal reasons and motivation to your legal case.
landing_page.section7Dropdown2Title: Why does expungement or reclassification matter to me?
landing_page.section7Dropdown2Paragraph:
The word “expungement” can be confusing. Expungement means that in most cases your past criminal record cannot be used against you when applying for a job, housing or student loans. You also regain some of your rights like serving on a jury or owning a gun.

Even though your criminal record does not disappear from the public record forever, your record will be updated to show that the conviction has been dismissed.

Reclassification allows you to change past felony convictions to a misdemeanor, even if you have served a sentence and parole. Once the felony has been removed from your criminal record, you may be eligible for benefits not previously available to you.
landing_page.section7Dropdown3Title: Can law enforcement get a search warrant to access my data on this site?
landing_page.section7Dropdown3Paragraph:
No. Even if law enforcement were to search this site for your data, there would be no data to find. We do not store or save any of your data, ever. There would be nothing to find.

Once your data has left our site via download, it is your responsibility to keep your data secure.
landing_page.sectionParagraph8: Expunge Assist is currently looking for partner organizations to refine and tailor the product to the needs of their organizations. Contact us to learn more.

before_you_begin_page.sectionParagraph1: Be sure you are eligible for expungement. If you’re not sure, the <Link target='_blank' href="https://selfhelp.courts.ca.gov/clean-your-record">California Courts Self-Help Guide</Link> or the <Link target='_blank' href="https://roadmap.rootandrebound.org/understanding-cleaning-up-your-criminal-record/cleaning-up-your-criminal-record-later-in-reentry/california-expungement-of-state-convictions/chart-which-type-of-expungement-am-i-eligible-for/">Roadmap to Reentry</Link> can help you get started.
before_you_begin_page.sectionParagraph2: This process may take 30 minutes or longer so it's important that you give yourself enough time to complete your declaration.
before_you_begin_page.sectionParagraph3: If you have questions, check our <Link target='_blank' href="/faq">FAQ</Link>.
before_you_begin_page.sectionParagraph4: Using your browser’s back, forward, or refresh buttons will erase your answers. Be sure to use our “next” and “back” buttons only, and keep your browser window open until you are done.

welcome_page.description: This tool will guide you through writing your declaration. You can preview your declaration and make changes at the end of each section.

point1.content: Remember to avoid using informal language, such as abbreviations, slang and profanity:
point1.yes: Judge LastName, job, Department of Justice

point2.content: Remember to answer in complete sentences and use punctuation (like periods) at the end:
point2.yes: I want to expunge my record because I want to apply for jobs.

point3.content: Be sure to use “the first person” when answering questions. This is from your point of view:
point3.no: Kim wants to clear their record.
point3.yes: I want to clear my record.

advice_page.followUp: Keep your responses between 3-5 sentences for each section.

faq_page.page_subheader: This guide will help you learn more about declarations and how to use the tool.
faq_page.paragraph1.1a: Expungement of a past criminal conviction in California means that the conviction is dismissed. It is also called “record clearance,” “dismissal,” or “record relief.”
faq_page.paragraph1.1b: If your conviction is eligible for dismissal but is not eligible for automatic dismissal, you can apply to, or “petition”, the court for it to be dismissed.
faq_page.paragraph1.1c: Expungement lifts many of the negative effects of a criminal conviction and can give you a fresh start in your life.
faq_page.paragraph1.2a: A declaration in California is a written statement in a petition for expungement or reduction of some infractions, misdemeanors, or felonies. It may be required or may be added as supporting evidence depending on your case.
faq_page.paragraph1.2b: It is a written letter that explains why dismissal of your conviction would be in the interest of justice. It allows you to tell the judge your story and describe your circumstances, efforts to reform, and motivation for expungement or reduction. It is often about one page long.
faq_page.title1.3: Why does reduction or expungement matter to me?
faq_page.paragraph1.3a: Expungement means that in most cases your past criminal conviction cannot be used against you when applying for a job, housing, state licensing, or student loans. You may also regain some of your rights, like, in some cases, owning a firearm.
faq_page.paragraph1.3b: Reduction, also called “reclassification” or “redesignation”, allows you to change a past felony conviction to a misdemeanor, or a misdemeanor to an infraction, even if you have served a sentence. Certain legal provisions allow a felony conviction to be reduced to a misdemeanor and then be expunged.
faq_page.title1.4: What is the process for expungement in California?
faq_page.paragraph1.4a: To learn more about the process and eligibility for expungement in California, please check the following California Courts and California Legislature resources:
faq_page.paragraph1.4b: California Records Self-Help Guide: Clean your record
faq_page.paragraph1.4c: Clearing Your Adult Criminal Record in California: A Step-by-Step Guide
faq_page.paragraph2.1a:
Expunge Assist is a free step-by-step tool that helps people with past convictions in California write a declaration. This is one part of the process for expungement.

This tool is provided for free by Hack for LA, a project under the nonprofit Civic Tech Structure.
faq_page.paragraph2.1b: This is not a replacement for legal advice.
faq_page.title2.2: How does Expunge Assist protect my privacy?
faq_page.paragraph2.2a: Expunge Assist does not store or save any of your data. Once you close your browser, your data is cleared. If any person or agencies were to search this site for your data, there would be no data to find. However, once you have downloaded, saved, or copied your declaration from our site to another location, it is your responsibility to keep that data secure.
faq_page.paragraph2.2b: Check our Privacy Policy to learn more.
faq_page.title2.3: My conviction was not in California. Can I still use Expunge Assist?
faq_page.paragraph2.3a: This tool is currently intended only for people with past convictions in California. Each state has different rules for expungement, so you should check the laws of the state in which you have your conviction.
faq_page.paragraph2.3b: However, if your state requires or allows a declaration for expungement, then you may want to take a look at the Expunge Assist declaration generator as a guide for the writing process or to help get a better idea of what a declaration may contain.
faq_page.title2.4: I see incorrect information on this website. What should I do?
faq_page.paragraph2.4a: Get in touch at expungeassist@hackforla.org. The laws change often in California, and that could mean some information is outdated in this website. We work to provide correct information, so please let us know if we missed something.
faq_page.paragraph2.4b: Please note: The information provided here is only a brief overview. We encourage you to speak with a lawyer or legal aid organization to learn about the pathway to expungement for your individual case.
faq_page.title2.5: What if I have a question about Expunge Assist or the declaration generator that has not been answered?
faq_page.paragraph2.5a: If you have questions specific to Expunge Assist or Hack for LA such as about our site, the declaration generator, or operations and partner organizations, please reach out at expungeassist@hackforla.org, and we will try our best to answer them.
faq_page.paragraph2.5b: If you have a question about the laws or are seeking legal advice for your individual case, then you should contact a lawyer or local legal aid organization.
